School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Guizhou University Guiyang Guizhou 550025 China Developing high-performance catalysts for direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2; DSHP) remains challenging. The paper proposes a strategy to optimize Pd catalysts by enriching Ni-modified N-doped porous carbon. The theoretical studies indicate that Ni modulates the electronic structure of Pd through charge transfer and strain effects, effectively reducing the adsorption energy of reaction intermediates. Furthermore, the Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (COHP) analysis demonstrated that the energy-integrated COHP (ICOHP) of the OO bonds in O2* (* denotes the adsorbed state), OOH*, and HOOH* were positively correlated with dissociation activation energies and negatively correlated with hydrogenation activation energies. The modulation of the electronic structure of Pd by Ni reduces the hydrogenation activation energies of O2* and OOH* and increases the dissociation activation energies of O2*, OOH*, and HOOH*, thereby enhancing the selectivity and productivity of H2O2. The experimental results aligned with the theoretical predictions, showcasing that the optimized Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs catalyst exhibited remarkable H2O2 selectivity and productivity of 70.5 % and 230.31 mol kgcat -1·h-1, respectively, surpassing the performance of Pd/NPCs (47.1 % and 52.3 mol kgcat -1·h-1). This study offers profound insights into the crucial role of electron effects in DSHP using nickel-modified palladium catalysts, providing strong evidence into the design and optimization of Pd catalysts. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni modification Pd-based catalyst Supported catalyst Direct synthesis of H2O2 Electronic structure Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), an efficient, environmentally friendly oxidant, has been widely used in industries such as papermaking, textiles, wastewater treatment, electronics manufacturing, and healthcare [1]. Currently, The production of hydrogen peroxide predominantly relies on the anthraquinone process. However, this process is hindered by its complexity, energy-intensive, and requires extensive use of costly and toxic organic solvents. Additionally, the instability of hydrogen peroxide presents substantial risks for the storage, transportation, and use of high-concentration hydrogen peroxide [2]. Therefore, there has been a continuous search for a rapid, environmentally friendly, and mild process for preparing hydrogen peroxide to address issues related to its application in scenarios involving low concentrations, low consumption, and reaction coupling [3]. DSHP utilizing hydrogen and oxygen as raw materials under the influence of a Pd-based catalyst offers advantages such as a streamlined process, reduced energy consumption, and prompt synthesis. This method is a potential alternative to the anthraquinone process [4]. However, Pd, as a reactive transition metal, tends to favor the production of the byproduct H2O over catalyzing the formation of hydrogen peroxide when facilitating the reaction between H2 and O2. This inclination significantly impedes the industrial application of DSHP from hydrogen and oxygen [5]. Consequently, the central focus of research has consistently been on the structural adjustment of Pd-based catalysts to enhance the productivity and selectivity of H2O2. Introducing noble metals such as Au [6–16], Pt [17–19], and Ag [20,21] to form alloys with Pd is an essential method for tuning the performance of Pd-based catalysts. For instance, PdAu bimetallic alloys can offer catalytic rates and selectivity surpassing those of monometallic palladium or gold catalysts, making them widely applicable in DSHP [8–15]. Additionally, studies indicate that geometric effects primarily influence the selectivity of H2O2 in PdAu alloy catalysts. Specifically, when the Pd/Au ratio increases to 1/220, the selectivity of H2O2 approaches 100 % [9]. However, using noble metals enhances catalytic activity and significantly increases catalyst preparation costs, posing challenges for large-scale industrial applications. Non-noble metals such as Sn [22–24], Zn [25], Pb [26,27], Cu [28,29], and Ni [30–33] can also modulate the catalytic activity of Pd through electronic or geometric effects. For example, Nugraha et al. [30], using Density functional theory (DFT) calculations discovered that PdNi@Pd(111) exhibits higher favorability for H2O2 synthesis compared to Pd(111). Eswaramoorthy et al. study [31] indicated that Ni doping enhances the activity and stability of Pd-based catalysts, with prepared Pd-Ni bimetallic catalysts achieving three times the H2O2 productivity compared to single Pd catalysts and capable of continuous operation for over 72 h. Crole et al. [32] observed that the prepared 0.5 %Pd–4.5 %Ni/TiO2 catalyst significantly improved H2O2 selectivity. Hwang et al. [33] demonstrated that an ordered PdNi alloy strengthens the metal-support interaction, resulting in increased H2O2 productivity (83.3 mol·kg−1·h−1) and selectivity (96 %). Recently, it has been reported that Ni modification of Al2O3 can facilitate the transfer of electrons from Pd nanoparticles to the modified carrier, leading to Pd being in an electron-deficient state, which is favorable for the adsorption and semi-hydrogenation catalysis of phenylacetylene [34]. The potential of Ni as a transition metal to modulate the electronic structure of Pd is well recognized. However, research on using transition metal Ni to modify porous carbon to optimize the electronic structure of Pd and enhance the activity of Pd-based catalysts in DSHP is still relatively limited. In this study, two Pd-based catalysts, Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111), were designed to investigate the mechanism of Ni modulation on the electronic structure and catalytic performance of Pd through DFT calculations. The results show that the difference in electronegativity between Pd and Ni promotes electron transfer from Ni to Pd, leading to an electron-rich state of Pd. Simultaneously, the strain effect between Pd and Ni increases the overlap of the d orbital electron clouds of Pd, shifting the d-band center toward lower energy levels. The modulation of the electronic structure of Pd by Ni reduces the hydrogenation activation energies of O2* and OOH* and increases the dissociation activation energies of O2*, OOH*, and HOOH*, thereby improving the productivity and selectivity of H2O2. Based on the DFT study, Pd catalysts supported on Ni-modified nitrogen-doped porous carbons (Pd-Ni/NPCs) were prepared using the substitution method to investigate further the effect of Ni modification on the Pd electronic structure and the catalytic activity for DSHP. The optimized Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs catalyst showed excellent H2O2 productivity (230.31 mol kgcat -1 h-1) and selectivity (70.5 %) under mild conditions. The experimental results are consistent with the theoretical expectations. This study emphasizes the significant role of nickel modification in optimizing the electronic structure of active metal and enhancing the catalytic performance for DSHP of hydrogen peroxide, providing new insights for applying non-noble metals in this field. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Calculation method The periodic spin-polarized DFT calculations were performed using the VASP software package [35,36], employing the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) and PBE functionals [37] for electronic exchange and correlation energies. The interaction between core and valence electrons was treated with the projector augmented wave (PAW) method [38,39]. Long-range van der Waals interactions were described using the DFT-D3 method [40,41]. A plane-wave basis set with a cutoff energy of 400 eV was used, and the convergence criteria for structure optimization were set to electronic energy changes less than 1 × 10–7 eV and forces less than 0.01 eV/Å. Monkhorst-Pack sampling with a 3 × 3 × 1 k-point grid was applied for Brillouin zone integration. For the transition state search of elementary reactions, the CI-NEB (climbing-image nudged elastic band algorithm) method [42,43] was initially employed to obtain approximate transition state structures, which were then optimized using the dimer method [44,45] to obtain accurate transition state structures. Subsequently, frequency analysis was conducted on the optimized transition states to confirm their correctness, using the criterion of having only one imaginary frequency. The convergence criteria for the transition state energy and forces were 1 × 10–7 eV and −0.03 eV/Å, respectively. The activation energy (Ea) and reaction energy (∆E) for elementary reactions were calculated using the following formulas: E a = E T S − E I S ▵ E = E F S − E I S Where EIS, EFS, and ETS represent the initial, final, and transition states of the elementary reaction. The adsorption energy (Eads(M)) for species M was calculated using the following formula: E a d s ( M ) = E M − s u r f a c e − E s u r f a c e − E M Here, EM-surface, Esurface, and EM represent the total energy of the adsorbate species after adsorption on the surface, the clean surface energy, and the adsorbate species' energy in the gas phase, respectively. Therefore, a more negative Eads(M) value indicates stronger adsorption of the corresponding species M on the surface. The calculations of activation energy (Ea), reaction energy (∆E), and adsorption energy (Eads) all include zero-point energy (ZPE) corrections. The rate constant for elementary reactions was calculated using Transition State Theory [46], and the formula for the rate constant is expressed as follows: k i = k B T h e − Δ G i ≠ 0 / k B T Here, kB is the Boltzmann constant, T is the temperature, h is the Planck constant, and ΔGi≠0 is the change in standard molar Gibbs free energy between the transition and initial states for the reaction i calculated using DFT. We used the VASPKIT code [47] and VESTA [48] to post-process the VASP calculated data. 2.2 Calculation model Herein, we first calculated the lattice constants of Pd and Ni to verify the reliability of the calculations. The calculation lattice constants of bulk Pd and Ni were determined to be 3.890 and 3.520 Å, respectively, which agrees well with the experimental values of Pd (3.891 Å) [49] and Ni (3.524 Å) [50]. The Pd(111) and Ni(111) surfaces were represented by a P(4 × 4) periodic supercell model consisting of four atomic layers. By substituting Pd for the topmost Ni atoms on the Ni(111) surface, we constructed the Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) models. The lattice mismatch between Pd and Ni causes contraction or expansion of the bimetallic surface lattice compared to the pure lattice plane. Therefore, we performed structural optimization on the substituted Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) models, which were then used for subsequent calculations. A vacuum layer of at least 15 Å was introduced to avoid interferences between the different surface models. The optimized structures of Pd(111), Ni(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are shown in Fig. S1. In all DFT calculations, the bottom two layers were fixated, and the upper two layers and the adsorbate species were allowed to relax. 2.3 Preparation of Pd-Ni/NPCs catalysts The nitrogen-doped porous carbons (NPCs) support was prepared using the method mentioned previously [51], and the specific preparation method can be found in the Supplementary Information (SI). The Pd-Ni/NPCs catalyst was prepared using the displacement method. Specifically, 47.3 mg of nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate (Ni(Ac)2·4H2O, NiC4H6O4·4H2O) was taken in a round-bottom flask, and 50 ml of ethylene glycol (EG) was added. The mixture was sonicated for 10 min to ensure completely dissolution of the nickel acetate tetrahydrate. Subsequently, 100 mg of NPCs was added, and the mixture was sonicated for 30 min to completely disperse the porous carbon. The pH of the reaction mixture was adjusted to 11 by dropwise addition of 1 M NaOH/EG solution. The reaction was stirred at 35 °C for 20 h and subjected to microwave-assisted sonication at 180 °C for 10 min. After centrifugation at 10,000 rpm for separation, 50 ml of deionized water was added to the supernatant, followed by sonication for 30 s. Then, 0.5 ml of 0.075 M H2PdCl4 solution was added, and the mixture was stirred at 28 °C for 20 h before centrifugation. The catalyst was dried overnight at 80 °C. The dried catalyst was placed in a tube furnace and heated in an air atmosphere at a rate of 5 °C/min to 250 °C, held for 120 min, and then naturally cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, the temperature was increased to 250 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min in a hydrogen atmosphere, and the catalyst was maintained at 250 °C for 150 min. The prepared catalyst was named Pd-Ni5/NPCs. Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs and Pd-Ni10/NPCs were prepared using 70.5 mg and 93.5 mg of NiC4H6O4·4H2O, respectively. X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were used to investigate the structure and surface properties of catalysts. The details of the instruments are provided in the Supporting Information (SI). 2.4 Preparation of Pd/NPCs catalysts The Pd/NPCs catalyst was prepared using the impregnation method [52]. Specifically, 100 mg of NPCs was taken in a round-bottom flask, and 50 ml of deionized water was added. The mixture was sonicated for 30 min to ensure proper dispersion of the porous carbon. Then, 0.5 ml of 0.075 M H2PdCl4 solution was added, and the mixture was stirred at 28 °C for 20 h. After stirring, the mixture was centrifuged, and the resulting solid was dried overnight at 80 °C. The dried catalyst was placed in a tube furnace and heated in an air atmosphere at a rate of 5 °C/min to 250 °C, held for 120 min, and then naturally cooled to room temperature. Subsequently, the temperature was increased to 250 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min in a hydrogen atmosphere, and the catalyst was maintained at 250 °C for 150 min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The electronic structure of Pd We computed the average binding energies between Pd and Ni to evaluate the stability of the constructed catalyst structures. As shown in Table S1, the binding energies of Pd on the surfaces of Pd16/Ni(111), Pd9/Ni(111), and Pd(111) are −1.16, −2.48, and −1.14 eV, respectively. The binding energies of Pd on the surfaces of Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) are both lower than those on the Pd(111) surface, indicating that the stability of Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are more crucial than Pd(111) surface. The higher electronegativity of Pd than that of Ni (Pauling electronegativity scale: Ni: 1.91, Pd: 2.20) [53–56] results in electron transfer from Ni to Pd when Pd is loaded onto the Ni surface. Differential charge analysis of Pd9/Ni(111) and Pd16/Ni(111) reveals this electron transfer between Ni and Pd. As shown in Fig. 1 a and b, the charge density decreases around Ni atoms and increases around Pd atoms, indicating electron transfer from Ni to Pd and leading to a charge delocalization effect. Fig. 2 S shows that in Pd16/Ni(111), electrons primarily transfer from the subsurface Ni to the surface Pd, while in Pd9/Ni(111), electron transfer mainly occurs between the surface Ni and Pd layers. Bader charge analysis shows that surface Pd in Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) gain 0.12 e and 0.19 e of electrons, respectively. The surface Pd receives electrons from bulk Ni and has the benefit of maintaining its metallic state. The atomic diameter of Ni is 1.62 Å [57–59], and that of Pd is 1.79 Å [60–62]. When the atoms of the Ni(111) surface are replaced by Pd, the lattice mismatch between Pd and Ni leads to compression of the Pd-Pd bonds. As shown in Fig. S1, the length of Pd-Pd bonds on the surfaces of Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) are 2.555 and 2.593 Å, respectively, both lower than that of Pd(111) surface (2.752 Å). The compression of Pd-Pd bonds increases the overlap of Pd atom d-orbital electron clouds, widening the d-band and shifting the d-band center toward lower energy levels. As shown in Fig. 1c, the d-band centers of Pd on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), Pd9/Ni(111), and Ni(111) surfaces (Ni atom) are −1.50, −2.20, −2.06, and −1.22 eV, respectively, which is consistent with the expectation. This indicates that changing the Pd-Ni ratio changes the d-band center of Pd. According to the d-band center theory, the d-band center of transition metals is crucial for surface catalysis. When the d-band center of a transition metal approaches the Fermi level, its adsorption energies for surface species increase [63], thereby influencing surface catalytic reaction processes. It is well known that both strain and ligand effects influence the electronic structure of active metals, thereby altering their catalytic activity [64–68]. The electronic structure of Pd on Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces is affected by both strain and ligand effects induced by Ni. However, distinguishing the contributions of these two effects to the electronic structure of Pd is challenging when they coexist. To investigate the extent of strain and ligand effects on the electronic structure of surface Pd, we replaced Ni atoms with Pd atoms on the Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces and substituted some Pd atoms with Ni atoms in the Pd(111) structure. The results, as shown in Fig. S3, indicate that strain effects lower the d-band center of Pd on Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces by 0.66 and 0.55 eV, respectively, whereas ligand effects reduce the d-band center by 0.28 and 0.24 eV. Therefore, the strain effects on the electronic structure of Pd are stronger than the ligand effects on both Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces. 3.2 The influence of Pd's D-band center on adsorption performance The change in the transition metal's d-band center can affect the adsorption energies of surface species. We separately calculated the adsorption energies of various intermediate species on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces to explore the influence of Pd's d-band center on the main reactant species in the DSHP. The optimized adsorption sites of all species are shown in Fig. S4, while the adsorption energies and OO bond lengths are presented in Table 1 . As shown in Table 1, the adsorption energies of all species on the Pd(111) surface are higher than those on Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111), consistent with expectations. Compared to Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111), the d-band center of Pd(111) is closer to the Fermi level, making the surface more active and more conducive to adsorption. As shown in Fig. 2, the adsorption energies of different intermediate species are strongly correlated with the d-band center of Pd. As the d-band center of Pd decreases (moves away from the Fermi level), its adsorption energies for various intermediate species gradually decrease, indicating that modulating the d-band center of Pd could regulate the adsorption energies of various intermediate species in DHSP. 3.3 The dissociation and hydrogenation reactions of O2 on different surfaces From a thermodynamic perspective, hydrogen and oxygen can DSHP and produce water as a byproduct [5]. O2*, OOH*, and HOOH* are critical intermediate products in DSHP. The degree of activation of these intermediates directly affects hydrogen peroxide production. According to Table 1, the adsorption energies of O2 on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are −1.05, −0.44, and −0.57 eV, respectively. The lower adsorption energies on Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces inhibit the excessive adsorption of O2. The bond lengths of the OO bonds after adsorption are 1.373, 1.326, and 1.337 Å, respectively, all of which exceed the bond length of gaseous oxygen (1.24 Å). This indicates that the adsorbed O2 is sufficiently activated, and the activation degree follows the trend Pd(111) > Pd9/Ni(111) > Pd16/Ni(111), consistent with the d-band center change of Pd. To study the dissociation and hydrogenation abilities of O2* on different surfaces, we first calculated the dissociation reaction energies and activation energies of O2*. The dissociation reaction energies of O2* on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are −1.92, −0.81, and −1.06 eV, respectively. Such high reaction energies imply that O2 is unlikely to reform into free O2 after dissociation. H2O is the final product after O2 dissociation, so inhibiting the dissociation of O2* is a critical step in DSHP. The dissociation activation energies of O2* on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are 0.56, 0.70, and 0.85 eV, respectively. The higher dissociation activation energies of O2* on the surfaces of Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) improve H2O2 selectivity. Furthermore, we calculated the reaction energies and activation energies of O2* hydrogenation on these surfaces. The reaction energies of O2* hydrogenation on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are 0.34, −0.21, and −0.16 eV, respectively, with activation energies of 0.88, 0.67, and 0.59 eV. It implies that the Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are more conducive to the formation of OOH*. To gain a better understanding of the catalytic activity of Pd surfaces toward O2, we researched its electronic properties. The findings indicate that the d orbitals of Pd play a critical role in the adsorption and activation of O2. Hence, we calculated the Projected Density of States (PDOS) and Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (COHP) [69] of O2*, further elucidating the interaction of d-2π* orbitals. Fig. 3 a shows an energy overlap region between the 2π* orbital of O2 and the d orbitals of Pd. When O2 is adsorbed on the surface of Pd, the 2π* orbital of O2 interacts with the d orbitals of Pd. This interaction causes a splitting of energy levels, leading to some antibonding 2π* orbitals being lowered below the Fermi level. This allows electrons to transfer from the Pd surface into O2*. For the Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111) (Fig. S5), and Pd9/Ni(111) (Fig. S6) surfaces, the antibonding 2π* orbitals of oxygen are partially filled, indicating a weakening of the OO bond and activation of O2*. The overlap of the PDOS orbitals of O2* and Pd suggests a covalent bond between Pd and O. To explain the interactions between OO and Pd-O, we used the integrated crystal orbital Hamilton population (ICOHP) as a quantitative descriptor for OO and Pd-O bonding. The ICOHP values provide an estimate of the bond energy (the more negative the value, the stronger the bonding strength) [70]. Therefore, the activation degree of the O2 decreases as the ICOHP decreases, indicating that the more negative the ICOHP, the lower the activation degree of the O2. The ICOHP of the OO bond for O2* on the Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces (Fig. S7) are −10.782, −10.780, and −11.038 eV, respectively, all higher than free O2 (−15.990 eV). This indicates that O2* is sufficiently activated, and the activation degree follows the trend Pd(111) > Pd16/Ni(111) > Pd9/Ni(111). This trend is consistent with the changes in O2 dissociation activation energies. The adsorption and activation of O2 are crucial steps in DSHP. However, the excessively activated O2* is more likely to dissociate into O* atoms, ultimately forming water as a byproduct. It is worth noting that the activation degree of O2* on different surfaces shows an opposite trend to the change in activation energies of O2* hydrogenation, which indicates that adjusting the activation degree of O2* could concomitantly control the dissociation and hydrogenation of O2*, with a lower activation degree of O2 being beneficial for improving the selectivity of H2O2. Fig. S8 shows that the ICOHP for the Pd-O covalent bonds on the Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are −2.213, −1.765, and −1.836 eV, respectively, indicates that the bond strength of the Pd-O covalent bond on the Pd(111) surface is stronger than that on the Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces. Notably, the trend of ICOHP for the Pd-O covalent bond aligns with the trend of O2 adsorption energies on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces. A lower ICOHP for the Pd-O covalent bond indicates stronger adsorption of O2 on the surface. The PDOS analysis of O2* indicates that when O2 is adsorbed on the Pd surface, electrons transfer from the Pd to O2*, resulting in excess electrons on O2*. Bader charge analysis shows that the charge number of O2* on the Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are 0.58, 0.43, and 0.46 e, respectively. There are two noteworthy points: firstly, the charge number of O2* is not related to the surface charge of Pd but is positively correlated with its d-band center, indicating that the electronic structure of Pd is the key factor influencing the catalytic performance of H2O2. Secondly, The excess electrons of O2* are also positively correlated with the ICOHP of Pd-O and negatively correlated with the adsorption energy of O2*. As the additional electrons on O2* increase, the OO bond weakens, thereby facilitating the dissociation of O2*. 3.4 The dissociation and hydrogenation reactions of OOH on different surfaces The OOH* is also an essential intermediate in DSHP. The adsorption energies of OOH* on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are −1.48, −1.02, and −1.18 eV, respectively, all higher than that of O2*, which indicates that OOH* can be more stably adsorbed on the Pd surface. The OO bond lengths of OOH* are 1.53, 1.448, and 1.489 Å, respectively, all longer than the O2*, indicating that the addition of hydrogen weakens the energy of OO bond. We calculated the dissociation reaction energies and activation energies to investigate the dissociation and hydrogenation properties of OOH*. The results show that the dissociation reaction energies of OOH* on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are −2.01, −1.21, and −1.43 eV, respectively. Such high dissociation reaction energies mean it is difficult for OOH* to re-form after dissociation. The O* and OH* generated by dissociation are ultimately converted into water (H2O), so inhibiting the dissociation of OOH* is also an essential step in DSHP. The dissociation activation energies of OOH* on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are 0.08, 0.30, and 0.13 eV, respectively, indicating that the dissociation of OOH* is relatively tricky on Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces. It should be noted that the dissociation activation energy of OOH* on the Pd(111) surface is 0.08 eV. This value differs significantly from the one calculated by Tian et al. (0.33 eV) [71] but aligns well with the value calculated by Sun et al. (0.00 eV) [72]. The difference is related to the transition state structure obtained by the calculations. Subsequently, we calculated the reaction energies and activation energies for the hydrogenation of OOH*. On the surfaces of Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111), the reaction energies were 0.2, −0.52, and −0.31 eV, respectively, while the corresponding activation energies were 0.73, 0.31, and 0.45 eV. These results indicate that the Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are more conducive to OOH* hydrogenation. We employed ICOHP as a descriptor to investigate the impact of the OO and Pd-O bonds in OOH* on its dissociation, hydrogenation, and adsorption. Similar to O2*, we use the ICOHP value of the OO bond in OOH* to describe the activation degree of OOH*, where a more negative ICOHP value indicates a lower activation degree of OOH*. As shown in Fig. 4 , compared to Pd(111), the antibonding orbitals of the OO bonds on Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces below the Fermi level are shifted upward, leading to an increase in the OO bond energy. The ICOHP values of OOH* on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are −6.319, −8.377, and −7.307 eV, respectively. Therefore, the activation degree of the OO bond in OOH* follows the trend Pd(111) > Pd9/Ni(111) > Pd16/Ni(111), which is consistent with the trend in the dissociation activation energies of OOH*. The activation of OOH* is an important step in DSHP. However, excessively activated OOH* is more susceptible to dissociation, leading to the formation of the byproduct water. Notably, the activation degree of OOH* is inversely related to the OOH* hydrogenation activation energies trend, indicating that regulating the activation degree of OOH* can simultaneously control both the dissociation and hydrogenation steps of OOH*. Lowering the activation degree of OOH* is advantageous for enhancing the selectivity of H2O2. As shown in Fig. S9, the ICOHP values of the Pd-O covalent bonds formed between OOH* and Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are −3.374, −2.182, and −2.501 eV, respectively. These values align with the trend of OOH* adsorption energies, indicating that the more negative the ICOHP value of the Pd-O covalent bond, the stronger the adsorption of OOH* onto the surface. 3.5 Adsorption and dissociation of HOOH on different surfaces The desorption of HOOH* represents the final step in generating H2O2. Calculations show that the adsorption energies of HOOH* on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are −0.5, −0.47, and −0.48 eV, respectively, which considerable lower than those of other species (such as O, H, OH, and OOH). The lower adsorption energy promotes the prompt detachment of generated H2O2 from the Pd surface and diffusion into the reaction medium. Additionally, the dissociation of HOOH* also plays a crucial role in the productivity and selectivity of H2O2. The dissociation reaction energies of HOOH* on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are −1.98, −1.29, and −1.65 eV, with activation energies of 0.28, 0.41, and 0.30 eV, respectively. This indicates that OOH* is relatively challenging to dissociate on Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces. The d orbitals of Pd play an important role in the adsorption and dissociation of HOOH. Therefore, we calculated the PDOS and COHP of HOOH* to further explain the interaction between Pd and HOOH. Fig. S10 shows an overlap between the 3π*, 4π*, and 6σ* orbitals of O in HOOH and the d orbitals of Pd. When HOOH adsorbs on the Pd surface, the 3π* and 4π* orbitals of O interact with the d orbitals of Pd, while the 6σ* orbital splits, with some of the 6σ* orbitals located below the Fermi level, resulting in the flow of electrons from the Pd surface to HOOH. We analyzed the OO and Pd-O bond energies in HOOH* using COHP. As shown in Fig. 5 , the ICOHP values of the OO bonds in free HOOH and HOOH* adsorbed on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are −7.737, −7.556, −7.695, and −7.650 eV, respectively. It indicates that the OO bonds of HOOH* are weakened. Notably, the changing trend of ICOHP for OO bonds in HOOH* align with the dissociation activation energies of HOOH*. Thus, a more negative ICOHP value of the OO bond indicates more incredible difficulty in HOOH dissociation. Fig. S11 shows that the ICOHP values of the Pd-O covalent bond formed between HOOH* and Pd follow a consistent trend with the HOOH* adsorption energies. Specifically, a more negative ICOHP value of the Pd-O covalent bond indicates stronger adsorption of HOOH*. 3.6 H2O2 direct synthesis on different surfaces As previously discussed, in the DSHP, the primary reaction involves the two-step hydrogenation of O2 to produce H2O2. Concurrently, the dissociation of OO bonds in O2*, OOH*, and HOOH* acts as a competitive side reaction in H2O2 generation. Reducing the activation energies of the main reaction and increasing the activation energies of the side reaction can improve the catalytic performance of the DSHP. To further investigate the reaction mechanism of DSHP on Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces, we determined the reaction energies and activation energies of each elementary reaction step using DFT calculations (Table S2). Fig. 6 shows the energy changes of elementary reaction steps in DSHP on the Pd(111) surface. The figure shows that H2 and O2 exhibit high adsorption energies of −1.30 and −1.05 eV, respectively. The dissociation and hydrogenation of O2* are competitive reactions in DSHP. The reaction energies and activation energies for the hydrogenation of O2* are 0.34 and 0.88 eV, respectively, both higher than the reaction energies and activation energies for the dissociation of O2* (−1.92 and 0.56 eV), indicating that O2* is more prone to decompose into O* atoms rather than undergo hydrogenation to form OOH*. Similarly, the dissociation and hydrogenation of OOH* are also competitive reactions. The reaction energies and activation energies for the hydrogenation of OOH* are 0.22 and 0.73 eV, respectively, while those for dissociation are −2.01 and 0.08 eV, respectively. This implies that on the Pd(111) surface, OOH* is more likely to decompose into OH* and O* rather than undergo hydrogenation to form HOOH*. The investigation into O2*, OOH* hydrogenation, and dissociation on the Pd(111) surface revealed that hydrogen and oxygen preferentially promote the formation of H2O over H2O2. Fig. 7 shows the energy changes of elementary reaction steps in DSHP on the Pd16/Ni(111) surface. The adsorption energies of H2 and O2 on the Pd16/Ni(111) surface are −0.51 and −0.44 eV, respectively, considerably lower than those on the Pd(111) surface (−1.30 and −1.05 eV). This indicates that the Pd16/Ni(111) surface inhibits the adsorption of H2 and O2, potentially decreasing the coverage of H and O2 on the catalyst surface. Compared to Pd(111), the dissociation activation energy of O2* increases from 0.56 to 0.70 eV, and the hydrogenation activation energy of O2* decreases from 0.88 to 0.67 eV, indicating that the Pd16/Ni(111) surface is more favorable for the hydrogenation of O2. The hydrogenation reaction energies and activation energies of OOH* on the Pd16/Ni(111) surface are −0.52 and 0.31 eV, respectively, both higher than the dissociation reaction energies and activation energies (−1.21 and 0.30 eV), indicating that dissociation of OOH* is more advantageous than hydrogenation on the Pd16/Ni(111) surface. Compared to Pd(111), the hydrogenation activation energy of OOH* decreases from 0.73 to 0.31 eV, and the dissociation activation energy of OOH* increases from 0.08 to 0.30 eV, indicating that the Pd16/Ni(111) surface is more favorable for the hydrogenation of OOH*. Compared to Pd(111), the dissociation reaction energy of HOOH* decreases from −1.98 to −1.29 eV, and the dissociation activation energy of HOOH* increases from 0.28 to 0.41 eV, indicating that the Pd16/Ni(111) surface increases the difficulty of HOOH* dissociation, which is beneficial for improving the productivity and selectivity of H2O2. Fig. 8 shows the energy changes of elementary reaction steps in DSHP on the Pd9/Ni(111) surface. The adsorption energies of H2 and O2 are −0.65 and −0.57 eV, respectively, showing a considerable decrease compared to Pd(111), indicating that the Pd9/Ni(111) surface also suppresses the adsorption of H2 and O2. It is noteworthy that on the Pd9/Ni(111) surface, the hydrogenation reaction energies and activation energies of O2* (−0.16 and 0.59 eV, respectively) are lower than the dissociation reaction energies and activation energies (−1.06 and 0.85 eV), indicating that hydrogenation of O2* is more advantageous than dissociation. The hydrogenation activation energy of OOH* on the Pd9/Ni(111) surface (0.45 eV) is higher than the dissociation activation energy (0.13 eV). This suggests that the dissociation of OOH* is more advantageous than hydrogenation. A notable observation is that compared to Pd(111), on the Pd9/Ni(111) surface, the activation energy for OOH* hydrogenation decreased from 0.73 to 0.45 eV; the dissociation energy increased from 0.08 to 0.13 eV. Furthermore, the dissociation energy of HOOH* decreased from −1.98 to −1.65 eV, whereas the dissociation activation energy increased from 0.28 eV to 0.30 eV. These findings suggest that the Pd9/Ni(111) surface promotes OOH* hydrogenation and suppresses HOOH* dissociation. The analysis above shows that the metal Ni not only transfers electrons to Pd, leading to a specific negative charge on the Pd surface but also adjusts the Pd-Pd bond lengths through compressive stress, thereby altering the electronic structure of Pd. Compared to the Pd(111) surface, the d-band center of Pd on Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces are further away from the Fermi level, suppressing the activity of Pd. Due to the change in the electronic structure of Pd, the dissociation activation energies of O2*, OOH*, and H2O2* on Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces increase, while the hydrogenation activation energies of O2* and OOH* decrease. This indicates that the Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surfaces may be more conducive to DSHP. 3.7 Catalyst characterization and performance testing In DSHP, our goal is to decrease the rate of competitive side reactions while preserving a high rate for the primary response, thus enhancing the selectivity and productivity of H2O2. DFT calculations indicate that Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) are highly efficient catalysts for DSHP. Building on this finding, we utilized an electrochemical displacement method to fabricate a range of Pd-Ni/NPCs catalysts. The synthesis process of the Pd-Ni/NPCs catalysts is shown in Fig. 9 . Firstly, Ni is rapidly deposited onto the surface of nitrogen-doped porous carbon using an ultrasound-assisted microwave synthesis technique. Subsequently, the electrochemical displacement method is utilized to substitute Ni atoms with Pd atoms based on the potential difference between Ni and Pd. By adjusting the amount of added Ni(Ac)2, the Pd-Ni/NPCs catalysts with varying Ni/Pd atomic ratios were synthesized. The loading of Pd and Ni in the different catalysts was determined using ICP-OES (Table S3). Due to the etching effect of hydrochloric acid on Ni in the H2PdCl4 solution, the Ni/Pd atomic ratios determined by ICP-OES are lower than the theoretical values. Finally, the Ni/Pd atomic ratios of the Pd-Ni5/NPCs, Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs, and Pd-Ni10/NPCs catalysts are 1.81, 4.03, and 6.77, respectively. In the DFT calculations, we constructed the Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) models by substituting Pd atoms for Ni atoms on the Ni(111) surface. Initially, we conducted XRD measurements of the crystal structures of the catalysts to validate the consistency between the experimental and computational models, as shown in Fig. 10 a. ’Five peaks observed at 39.6°, 46.3°, 67.8°, 81.8°, and 86.1° for Pd/NPCs can be attributed to the (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222) crystal planes of Pd respectively (JCPDS# 87–0643) [22]. Similarly, distinct peaks corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), and (331) crystal planes of Pd (JCPDS# 87–0643) were observed in Pd-Ni5/NPCs, Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs, and Pd-Ni10/NPCs. With increasing Ni content, noticeable diffraction peaks appeared around 44.4° and 51.8° in Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs and Pd-Ni10/NPCs, which can be attributed to the (111) and (200) crystal planes of Ni (JCPDS# 04–0850) [73]. Notably, the Ni/NPCs did not exhibit significant diffraction peaks for metallic Ni, which may be related to its crystallinity and diaper. As shown in Fig. 10b, there were notable shifts toward higher angles in the Pd(111) and (200) diffraction peaks of Pd-Ni5/NPCs, Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs, and Pd-Ni10/NPCs catalysts, and the degree of shift increased with the increasing Ni content. The shifts of the Pd(111) diffraction peak toward higher angles indicate a reduction in the lattice spacing due to the addition of Ni. The smaller diameter of Ni atoms leads to compressive stress on Pd atoms when deposited on the Ni surface via displacement. This stress induces lattice contraction and compression of the Pd-Pd bond lengths, aligning with DFT calculations. Moreover, DFT calculations show that alterations in the Pd lattice can impact the electronic structure of Pd, thereby influencing the catalytic activity. With increasing Ni content, the intensity of the Pd(111) peak decreases, and the peak width increases, indicating that increasing the content of Ni can reduce the particle size of Pd nanoparticles. The average size of Pd nanoparticles of Pd/C catalysts was calculated using the Scherrer formula. The calculated Pd nanoparticle sizes of Pd/NPCs, Pd-Ni5/NPCs, Pd-Ni7.5NPCs, and Pd-Ni10/NPCs were 14.6, 15.1, 12.6, and 10.9 nm, respectively. We investigated the surface morphology and elemental distribution of Ni/NPCs using Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM). As shown in Fig. S12, the images reveal no significant aggregation of Ni nanoparticles on the surface of the NPCs. Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping further confirms that Ni is uniformly distributed on the surface of the NPCs. This observation is consistent with our experimental expectation, where the rapid reduction process using ultrasonic microwaves successfully deposits Ni on the surface of NPCs, thereby achieving the desired modification of NPCs. Fig. 11 a-b and Fig. S13 depict the TEM images and particle size distribution statistics of the Pd-Ni/NPCs catalysts. From the TEM images, it is evident that Pd nanoparticles are uniformly distributed on the NPCs. According to the particle size distribution statistics (Fig. 11b and Fig. S13), the average particle sizes of Pd/NPCs, Pd-Ni5/NPCs, Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs, and Pd-Ni10/NPCs were 26.8, 26.2, 22.5, and 18.7 nm, respectively. Notably, compared to Pd/NPCs, the average nanoparticle sizes of Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs and Pd-Ni10/NPCs catalysts reduced by 4.3 and 8.1 nm, respectively, indicating that increasing the amount of modified Ni can reduce the average nanoparticle sizes of Pd. It should be noted that there is a considerable difference between the average particle size obtained from the TEM and XRD measurements. This difference may stem from XRD measuring the average particle size of specific crystal planes, and the TEM primarily obtains particle size distribution through statistical methods. Figs. 11c and S14 show that all of the catalysts contain the (111) and (200) crystal planes of Pd, and Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs and Pd-Ni10/NPCs catalysts exhibit (111) crystal planes of Ni, aligning with XRD diffraction patterns. With the Ni content increasing, the lattice spacing of Pd decreases from 0.228 to 0.224 nm (Fig. S14), consistent with the XRD analyses. To better understand the composition of the catalysts, we used an EDX line scan to further investigate the composition of nanoparticles. As shown in Fig. S15b, Ni atoms are linearly distributed, while Pd atoms exhibit a volcano-like distribution. The line scan demonstrates that Ni atoms are evenly deposited on the NPCs support surface, and the volcano-like distribution of Pd atoms confirms their successful deposition on the surface of Ni. EDX analysis (Figure S15d) shows that Pd and Ni atoms constitute 11.58 % and 88.42 %, respectively. The HRTEM images of Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs (Fig. 11c) and Pd-Ni10/NPCs (Fig. S14c) reveal typical Ni(111) crystal planes on the surface of nanoparticles, further proving that Pd is doped into Ni. Fig. 11d-g present the distribution of Pd and Ni atoms on NPCs. Ni atoms are highly dispersed on the surface NPCs, appearing as small but scattered bright spots in the EDS figure (Fig. 11e), and Pd atoms predominantly cluster and distribute in the surface region of Ni atoms. Based on the above analysis, the experimental model could be simplified as two typical models: Pd fully deposited on the Ni surface and Pd partially deposited on the Ni surface, which align well with the Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) models. This distribution pattern of Ni and Pd atoms aligns with our expectations. The DFT calculations reveal that the electronegativity difference between Ni and Pd atoms promotes electron transfer from Ni to Pd. To further understand the electron transfer between Pd and Ni, we employed X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to investigate the chemical composition and valence states of the Pd-Ni/NPCs. As shown in Fig. 12 , the Pd 3d spectrum of Pd/NPCs can be deconvoluted into four distinct peaks, corresponding to Pd0 (∼341 eV, ∼335 eV) and Pd2+ (∼343 eV, ∼337 eV) states [74,75], indicating the presence of two valence states, Pd2+ and Pd0, in Pd/NPCs. By comparing the binding energy of Pd in the Pd/NPCs and Pd-Ni5/NPCs, it can be observed that the binding energy of Pd has reduced by 0.32 eV after Ni doping, indicating a higher proportion of the metallic states (Pd0); it demonstrates the electron transfer between Pd nanoparticles and Ni-modified NPCs, altering the original electronic structure of Pd. As the Ni content in the catalyst increases (Table S3), the binding energy of Pd continues to decrease (Table S4), further confirming the influence of Ni-modified support on the electronic structure of Pd. This observation is consistent with DFT calculations. The Ni 2p spectrum shows a complex structure with high binding energy satellite peaks formed by multi-electron excitations. After deconvolution considering these peaks, the Ni 2p spectra of Ni/NPCs, Pd-Ni5/NPCs, Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs, and Pd-Ni10/NPCs reveal the presence of Ni0 and Ni2+ (Fig. S16) [34,76,77], Compared to Ni2+, Ni° continually provides electrons to Pd during the reaction, maintaining the continuous presence of effective active sites on the Pd surface. Ni2+ may originate from oxidized nickel formed on the surface of nickel nanoparticles or insufficiently reduced nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate. In the O 1 s spectrum (Fig. S17) of Pd-Ni/NPCs, a characteristic peak near 530 eV, typical of metal oxides, is observed, which can be attributed to Ni metal oxides [78]. Compared to Pd-Ni5/NPCs, the peak area of metal oxides in Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs and Pd-Ni10/NPCs increased, indicating a gradual increase in the content of metal oxides in Ni with increasing Ni content. In summary, we employed various analytical techniques to validate the properties of the catalysts that had been prepared for Pd-Ni/NPCs. Experimental results from ICP-OES, XRD, TEM, and XPS effectively demonstrate that adding Ni can influence and modify the electronic structure of Pd. Specifically, 1) Ni atoms transfer electrons to Pd atoms, leading to electron accumulation on the Pd surface, and 2) the inclusion of Ni results in a reduction in surface Pd(111) lattice spacing. These findings agree with DFT calculations, demonstrating the correlation between the theoretical model and experimental structure. We evaluated the catalytic activities of the catalysts for DSHP in a continuous-flow reactor under atmospheric pressure. The results are shown in Table 2 . Compared to the Pd/NPCs catalyst prepared by impregnation, the Pd-Ni/NPCs catalysts prepared by displacement considerably enhanced the H2 conversion rate, H2O2 selectivity, and productivity. Specifically, the Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs catalyst achieved H2 conversion rate, H2O2 selectivity, and productivity of 51.3 %, 70.5 %, and 230.3 mol kgcat -1 h-1, respectively, higher than Pd/NPCs, indicating that the Pd-Ni/NPCs catalysts are more favorable for synthesizing H2O2. Early studies have indicated that the particle size and crystal facets of Pd substantially impact H2O2 synthesis [71,79]. TEM analyses revealed an average particle size of 18.7∼26.8 nm for the Pd-Ni/NPCs, and the particle distribution concentrated at 10–40 nm (Fig. 11b and Fig. S13). XRD analyses indicated that the catalysts both contain the (111), (200), (220), and (331) crystal facets of Pd. This suggests that the particle size and crystal facets may not be the primary factors affecting the performance differences between Pd/NPCs and Pd-Ni/NPCs. The chemical state of Pd plays a dual role in DSHP [7]; metallic Pd promotes H2 dissociation, increasing the conversion of H2, but also leads to the OO bond cleavage, decreasing the selectivity of H2O2. Conversely, Pd2+ could enhance the selectivity of H2O2 but reduce the conversion of H2. The Pd° content of the Pd/NPCs catalyst was only 24.70 % (Table S3), which inhibited H2 dissociation, resulting in a low H2 conversion rate (15.5 %). Notably, the Pd° content of the Pd-Ni5/NPCs catalyst is higher than Pd/NPCs; however, its H₂O₂ selectivity is considerably higher than Pd/NPCs. It is attributed to the electronic modulation of Pd by Ni. The difference in electronegativity between Ni and Pd promotes electron transfer from Ni to Pd, leading to electron enrichment on the Pd surface, which is beneficial for maintaining the metallic state of Pd. Concurrently, due to compressive stress, the Pd-Pd bonds on the Ni surface undergo compression (Fig. 11c and Fig. S14), enhancing the overlap of Pd atomic wavefunctions, broadening the energy band, and shifting the d-band center downward, and reducing the activity of Pd. DFT calculations showed that the d-band center of Pd on Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) surface is lower than Pd(111), which can inhibit the dissociation of O2* and OOH* and enhance the selectivity of H2O2. We employed the transition state theory (TST) [46] to calculate the dissociation rate constants of O2*, OOH*, and HOOH*, as well as the hydrogenation rate constants of O2* and OOH* (Table S5). For Pd(111), Pd16/Ni(111), and Pd9/Ni(111), the hydrogenation reaction rates of O2* are 3.75 × 10–4 s-1, 2.91 × 101 s-1, and 5.98 × 102 s-1, respectively, while the hydrogenation reaction rates of OOH* are 4.3 × 10–1 s-1, 7.45 × 105 s-1, and 9.81 × 103 s-1, respectively. These results indicate that the hydrogenation of O2* is the key step in DSHP. Additionally, the dissociation rates of OOH* are higher than O2* and HOOH*, suggesting that the dissociation of OOH* may be a key factor influencing H2O2 selectivity. It is worth noting that compared to the Pd9/Ni(111), Pd16/Ni(111) has a higher hydrogenation rate of OOH* and lower dissociation rates of OOH* and HOOH*. Therefore, Pd16/Ni(111) may exhibit higher H2O2 productivity and selectivity. According to Table 2, it can be observed that with the increase of Ni content, the productivity and selectivity of H2O2 exhibit a traditional volcano-shaped trend of initially increasing and then decreasing, which aligns well with DFT calculations. We conducted a prolonged activity test on Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs for three hours to investigate the stability of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 13 a, the concentration of H2O2 rapidly reached 0.063 % within 1 h, and it continued to increase steadily as the reaction progressed, demonstrating the sustained high catalytic activity of Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs throughout the reaction. As the reaction progressed, the H2O2 selectivity and H2 conversion rate slightly decreased. However, after three hours, the H2O2 selectivity and H2 conversion rate were still 61.6 % and 48.3 %, respectively, demonstrating the stability of Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs catalysis. We also evaluated the stability of the Pd/NPCs catalyst. As shown in Fig. S18, the concentration of H2O2 reached 0.014 % within 1 h; however, after 2 h, the concentration of H2O2 only reached 0.016 %, indicating that the Pd/NPCs catalyst was deactivated. The stability test of the Pd/NPCs catalyst demonstrated that Ni modification considerably enhances both the stability and activity of the catalyst. We compare the catalytic performance of the Pd-Ni/NPCs catalyst with other Pd-based catalysts; as shown in Table S6, the Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs catalyst effectively balances the trade-off between the selectivity and productivity of H2O2 and demonstrates excellent catalytic activity. All of these demonstrate the benefits of Ni modification in improving the catalytic performance of Pd-based catalysts. The reusability of a catalyst is a crucial metric for evaluating its performance. To investigate the reusability of the Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs catalyst, we conducted four consecutive cycles of experiments. As shown in Fig. S19, after four cycles, the productivity of H2O2 decreased from 224.2 mol kgcat -1 h-1 to 198.4 mol kgcat -1 h-1, the selectivity of H₂O₂ decreased from 72.3 % to 63.6 %. These results indicate that the Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs catalyst maintains good reusability after multiple cycles of use. To investigate the effect of the catalyst on the decomposition of H2O2, we evaluated the hydrogenation and decomposition abilities of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 13b, the hydrogenation rate exceeded the decomposition rate, suggesting that hydrogenation is the primary side reaction of H2O2 decomposition [82]. Notably, Pd-Ni/NPCs displayed a lower ability of H2O2 hydrogenation and decomposition than Pd/NPCs, indicating that the Pd-Ni/NPCs catalyst could inhibit the hydrogenation and decomposition of H2O2, aligning well with the DFT calculations. The DFT calculations revealed that Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) exhibited lower H2 dissociation energies and higher H2O2 dissociation activation energies than Pd(111), inhibited H2O2 dissociation and hydrogenation. 4 Conclusions In this paper, we first studied the impact of Ni modification on the DSHP through detailed DFT calculations. The results show that Ni modification exerts a substantial regulatory influence on the electronic structure of Pd, shifting the d-band center of Pd away from the Fermi level, which leads to a reduction in the adsorption energy of Pd for crucial reaction intermediates like O2*, H*, O*, OOH*, and HOOH*. Furthermore, we delved deeply into the surface reaction mechanism of the catalyst using ICOHP as a descriptor. The result demonstrates a positive correlation between ICOHP values of OO bonds in O2*, OOH*, and HOOH* with dissociation activation energies and a negative correlation with hydrogenation activation energies. In addition, the ICOHP values of Pd-O covalent bonds formed by O2*, OOH*, and HOOH* with Pd closely relate to surface reactions, which provides deeper insight into the reaction mechanism. Compared to Pd(111), both Pd16/Ni(111) and Pd9/Ni(111) exhibit reductions in the hydrogenation activation energies of O2* and OOH*, alongside increases in the dissociation activation energies of O2*, OOH*, and HOOH*. This dual effect is beneficial for the efficient synthesis of H2O2. Subsequently, according to the results of DFT calculations, we synthesized a range of Pd-Ni/NPCs catalysts and validated their performance against the theoretical model through experimental data. Notably, the Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs catalyst demonstrated considerable advantages in H2O2 production and sustained excellent catalytic activity throughout prolonged reaction periods. This study enhanced our comprehension of DSHP and furnished a robust theoretical and experimental foundation for optimizing catalyst design and performance. coredata.dc:description: Developing high-performance catalysts for direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2; DSHP) remains challenging. The paper proposes a strategy to optimize Pd catalysts by enriching Ni-modified N-doped porous carbon. The theoretical studies indicate that Ni modulates the electronic structure of Pd through charge transfer and strain effects, effectively reducing the adsorption energy of reaction intermediates. Furthermore, the Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (COHP) analysis demonstrated that the energy-integrated COHP (ICOHP) of the OO bonds in O2* (* denotes the adsorbed state), OOH*, and HOOH* were positively correlated with dissociation activation energies and negatively correlated with hydrogenation activation energies. The modulation of the electronic structure of Pd by Ni reduces the hydrogenation activation energies of O2* and OOH* and increases the dissociation activation energies of O2*, OOH*, and HOOH*, thereby enhancing the selectivity and productivity of H2O2. The experimental results aligned with the theoretical predictions, showcasing that the optimized Pd-Ni7.5/NPCs catalyst exhibited remarkable H2O2 selectivity and productivity of 70.5 % and 230.31 mol kgcat -1·h-1, respectively, surpassing the performance of Pd/NPCs (47.1 % and 52.3 mol kgcat -1·h-1). This study offers profound insights into the crucial role of electron effects in DSHP using nickel-modified palladium catalysts, providing strong evidence into the design and optimization of Pd catalysts.
